commit_message:
Add python-magic to requirements.

- Actively Maintained?
  Yes, this is a very popular Python package and it's maintainer
  Adam Hupp is very active within the project.

- Good code?
  Looks pretty good to me, currently tested via Travis and the
  tox coverage is very comprehensive.

- Python 3 compatable?
  Yes, compatible with Python 2.7 and 3.

- License?
  MIT

- Packaged as part of targetted distros?
  Ubuntu - Yes
  Fedora - Yes

- Is the functionality already covered?
  This package extends some functionality already provided within
  the Python built ins. The Python built in mimetypes simply uses
  a files extension to determine MIME type (not very comprehensive)
  however python-magic wraps libmagic and provides a much better
  method of identifying a files MIME type by using a bunch of
  signatures which are compared to parts of the file, and hence
  is much likely to return an accurate result.

- Which project is this for?
  This is intended to be used as part of the Nemesis project which
  aims to provide a file information and intelligence API for the
  OpenStack ecosystem. However I can imagine this would be useful
  for any project which needs to identify the type of a file with
  some accuracy.

Change-Id: I1382d1cd22275b03e3f0c6aff941d1c207e37faa

Thanks for fixing my bugs! I think a better approach would be to blacklist the falsey values. There are an infinite number of true constants, and Bandit shouldn't flag those.

As an additional finesse, `shell=variable` values could be flagged as lower-priority, since those may or may not be dangerous. But I think just flagging any non-false constant value would be good."}, {'account_id': 8119, 'date': '2016-12-19 19:24:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 12000, 'date': '2016-12-20 15:23:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Closes-Bug: #1650388

commit_message:
Handle several truth values for shell in subprocess

The current code only checks for shell=True, but Python allows
any truth value for that argument.

Change-Id: Icba606426bb615c592202148a1a6eeea712c2f26
Closes-Bug: #1650388

- gate-bandit-integration-sahara http://logs.openstack.org/41/281441/7/check/gate-bandit-integration-sahara/1467b17/ : FAILURE in 2m 28s (non-voting)'}, {'account_id': 12000, 'date': '2016-07-07 20:48:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: Code-Review-1

Having had to do some work with Flake8 recently, we join a lot of paths. I don't think this check would be useful in the slightest. Further, I feel like os.path.join is used sparingly enough in OpenStack that this won't catch very much."}, {'account_id': 18462, 'date': '2016-07-19 05:53:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review-1

I feel this *type* of test is more suited for Syntribos than bandit, Syntribos has some traversal, path-join type tests in its kitty.'}, {'account_id': 11861, 'date': '2016-12-19 17:02:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

I disagree with the -1's on this.  Without any filtering Bandit is designed to call attention to possible issues.  This does exactly that.  You can always disable it if it's too noisy and this is far from our only potentially noisy test."}, {'account_id': 18462, 'date': '2016-12-19 17:28:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+1

Think about the test a bit more, yeah I guess this can be a part of the tool, but I agree it would be noisy, if it serves to help a project in figuring out if they have not vetted the path, why not.'}, {'account_id': 18462, 'date': '2016-12-19 17:28:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: -Code-Review'}, {'account_id': 12000, 'date': '2016-12-19 18:34:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

Travis, my main concern is that even with this on "LOW" this will be several times more noisy (and less useful) than our current noisest test.

Think of it this way: PyLint is a *fantastic* tool that when unconfigured *overwhelms* first time users with information about the code they've written/are writing. If we start accepting changes like this, we're going to be the tool that people say "Oh no, I avoid that because by default it's *far* too noisy."

Bandit presently is quite useful with default settings (for most projects, maybe not most OpenStack projects, but otherwise yes I'd say *most* python projects). I really don't want Bandit to become a tool that has some bespoke configuration file that people pass around without understanding Why when they use it'}, {'account_id': 21420, 'date': '2017-12-14 22:46:29.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

Abandoning to clear up some of the review queue and it's been about a year without any update.

We can restore the change if/when someone gets bandwidth to pick this back up."}]

Please give feedback, this is experimental'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-10-15 17:14:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified-1

Build failed (check pipeline).  For information on how to proceed, see http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html#automated-testing

- gate-bandit-python34 http://logs.openstack.org/91/235491/1/check/gate-bandit-python34/1a473e6/ : FAILURE in 46s

- gate-bandit-python27 http://logs.openstack.org/91/235491/1/check/gate-bandit-python27/7c30a6d/ : SUCCESS in 43s'}, {'account_id': 11861, 'date': '2015-10-19 07:13:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Looks interesting, seems like a reasonable approach.  I'm really curious about:

1) What kind of performance penalties will this incur (both time and memory)

2) How will plugins generally leverage this?"}, {'account_id': 1528, 'date': '2015-10-19 08:46:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Apart from questions raised above, I'd be cautious of extra complexity. None of the static analysers for Python survived for very long - not sure what's the reason - but I expect that there's just too much information lost as values are assigned.

Even for constants propagation, this can potentially fail:

    self.a = "one"
    b = self.a

This code can have anything in `b` (fun with properties).

Then again, I appreciate that it's really useful, especially in case of code with limited line length. There's a good chance the plugin for key length detection won't be triggered, because someone did:

    x = cryptography.long_function_for_generating_private_keys
    key = x.generate('rsa', 256)

So, if it can stay minimal (constants folding, obvious "compile time" evaluation, etc.), it would be great to have it.'}, {'account_id': 11716, 'date': '2015-10-19 09:25:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Thanks for the comments, this is exactly the feedback I was hoping for.

@Travis
1: Not sure, would need to profile it, but it wont be free thats for sure.
2: This is experimental, but I would imagine tests using it to resolve names to some value that can be used in the their AST matching logic (a sub-tree block of AST nodes). Utils will emerge to do common things with the node collections returned.

@Stan
Your description is basically the sort of thing I'm heading for with this, indeed, keeping it simple is probably the trickiest bit. Your note about properties is an interesting one, really I see this as being a "best effort" mechanism, it will try to give a test more info but won't always be able to in every situation.'}, {'account_id': 11861, 'date': '2016-12-19 16:59:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I think we should get rid of this now?'}, {'account_id': 21420, 'date': '2017-12-14 22:46:03.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

Abandoning to clear up some of the review queue and it's been about a year without any update.

We can restore the change if/when someone gets bandwidth to pick this back up."}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2015-10-15 16:52:28.000000000', 'message': 'Adding symbol table

This is VERY experimental, mostly pushing this for feed back

This adds a symbol table that track various things we encounter
whwn processing the AST. We can use this info to do some deeper
inspection. At the moment this works with basic types, and handles
some limited expression solving. It can also make details about
method variables available within processing of a Call node

Example 1, we can work out that b is "str and some more str str "

	a = "str "
        c = "and" + " some " + "more "
        b = a + c + a * (4 / 2)

Example 2, we can work out that c is "one two"

	def foo(a, b):
            c = a + b

        foo("one ", "two")

Change-Id: Ia435fad81be33db411a3885a8ae2f174080267bf
'}]
commit_message:
Adding symbol table

This is VERY experimental, mostly pushing this for feed back

This adds a symbol table that track various things we encounter
whwn processing the AST. We can use this info to do some deeper
inspection. At the moment this works with basic types, and handles
some limited expression solving. It can also make details about
method variables available within processing of a Call node

Example 1, we can work out that b is "str and some more str str "

	a = "str "
        c = "and" + " some " + "more "
        b = a + c + a * (4 / 2)

Example 2, we can work out that c is "one two"

	def foo(a, b):
            c = a + b

        foo("one ", "two")

Change-Id: Ia435fad81be33db411a3885a8ae2f174080267bf

commit_message:
Some use of ftplib is properly secure

This patch changes the blacklist code to denote the difference
between using ftplib.FTP (insecure) versus ftplib.FTP_TLS (secure).

This also removes the ID B402, 'import of ftplib' and reorders the
ID numbers since IDs have not made it into a PyPi version yet.

Change-Id: I6ef3564ff0cedd2900bc4cdb3ac77cd84ae1bdbe
Closes-Bug: #1548186

commit_message:
Makefile: Allow pulling of all images for a targeted chart

This PS brings the OSH-Infra Make inline with OSH and allows images
to be pulled on a per chart basis to the local machine.

'force' parameter was missing from the 'PUT /os-quota-sets/{tenant_id}'

microversion 2.36 or later. The bug is now fixed so that the 'force'
parameter can once again be specified during quota updates. There is

commit_message:
Fix 'force' parameter in os-quota-sets PUT schema

A regression was introduced in the 2.36 API microversion where the
'force' parameter was missing from the 'PUT /os-quota-sets/{tenant_id}'
API request schema so users could not force quota updates with
microversion 2.36 or later. The bug is now fixed so that the 'force'
parameter can once again be specified during quota updates. There is
no new microversion for this change since it is an admin-only API.

Change-Id: I947e927802f755ccb25a91efd82cac895779d19e
Closes-Bug: #1733886
(cherry picked from commit 9ddbaa15cb55d1245a8a63d9414d134746fc2f3c)
(cherry picked from commit 6f5b3123cc3e35af7d9054c299f4c2232c8c2a3f)

commit_message:
Update names of helm test pods for openstack services

This updates the names of the helm test pods to give all services
in OSH-infra/OSH a uniform '{{ .Release.Name }}-test' name, which
allows for easier gathering of test results across all deployed
services

Change-Id: I24df7a18d32b99d1ffaad19647ef724316e2fe20

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-12-07 19:54:54.000000000', 'message': 'Use StrictHostKeyChecking=no in enable-ssh-admin.sh

Use StrictHostKeyChecking=no to inject the temporary ssh key in
enable-ssh-admin.sh. The user provides the list of hosts for ssh, so we
can safely assume that they intend to ssh to those hosts.

Also, for the ovb case the hosts will have new host ssh keys which have
not yet been accepted.

Change-Id: Ia2a2d1e4c214d9d9190131c280a54eab066e3657
Closes-Bug: #1737027
'}]
commit_message:
Use StrictHostKeyChecking=no in enable-ssh-admin.sh

Use StrictHostKeyChecking=no to inject the temporary ssh key in
enable-ssh-admin.sh. The user provides the list of hosts for ssh, so we
can safely assume that they intend to ssh to those hosts.

Also, for the ovb case the hosts will have new host ssh keys which have
not yet been accepted.

Change-Id: Ia2a2d1e4c214d9d9190131c280a54eab066e3657
Closes-Bug: #1737027

commit_message:
Don't use non promoted packages in stable branches

Current repo contain newest packages and should be used in master
jobs only. In stable branches we have to use only current-tripleo
repo which is promoted via promotion jobs.

Change-Id: I96c6ccf05b27e9f81c3e4eed6538b35e7739452f

commit_message:
Expose supported power states

This SPEC proposes adding a new API to expose supported power states of
nodes. This API would be helpful to see if a power action is supported
by a node because it depends on whether a power interface supports
power actions such as soft power off and soft reboot.

Change-Id: If4a3994376cd26a38ef4717bc215cd74df3591a8
Partial-Bug: 1734827

Needs middleware documentation so it is easier for users to know what symlink does and how to use it. Unless we want to keep it hidden for now, given that this is a preliminary implementation.

If this should be documented, notice that the middleware is documented in:

~/swift/doc/source/middleware.rst
Which actually links to the actual middleware class.
See bulk.py for an example.

This will be easy to maintain moving forward because every time the comments in symlink comments are updated, the documentation is automatically updated as well.'}, {'account_id': 16550, 'date': '2015-10-09 12:50:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 16550, 'date': '2015-10-09 12:52:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Workflow-1

This new patch set adds a func test that stresses the logic that merges headers between the symlink and the target object (to handle a post to a symlink, which actually only touches the symlink).

One issue currently in symlinks is the logic that fetches the swift_x_timestamp value, which I believe is incorrect, it is always falling back to the last modified value which only has second level granularity.  I believe this explains some of the random failures as well that exist in other testcases.

Finally note that I believe many of these func tests should probably be unit tests : )'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-10-11 00:00:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Verified+1

UPDATE:  I found a bug in terms of the header merging logic (not related to the timestamp) ... as it stands when  the SYMLINK is newer it merges in ALL headers from the symlink (and overwrite any matching ones from the target option).

Of course this ends up including content-length, implying we return the target object but with a 0 content-length.

We cannot blindly merge all headers and need to be careful here, other headers to avoid are likely:
etag
content-type
content-length
-- anything else ??? (timestamps ..)

BTW this explained some of the random failures when you hit:
    self.assertEqual(contents, REF_BODY)
AssertionError: '' != 'ref body'


As no body is returned.

I added a TC to stress this (which is currently failing) by simply sleeping for 1s before putting the symlink, to stress the code (FYI the 1s is due to the other issue with the swift_x_timpestamp logic being incorrect ... but in many ways it made this easier to hit)."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-10-15 23:11:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 19: Verified-1

(8 comments)

I really want to see some unit tests for this thing. Right now, if there's a crash in the middle of it, debugging is going to be a day of print statements and tears.

Check other places where we take booleans from the user. I'm pretty sure most of those will accept '1', 'yes', 'on', and 'true' in either lower or upper case. There's a config_true_value() function that handles this. If other user inputs are using config_true_value, then symlink should also do it for consistency."}, {'account_id': 16550, 'date': '2015-10-26 14:25:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 27.'}, {'account_id': 16550, 'date': '2015-10-26 14:48:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 26:

(7 comments)

As a result of talks in Tokyo plans are to change the behaviour of POST on symlink.  See swift-spec patch set 242804 for details.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-12-01 03:37:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 27: Verified-1

Merge Failed.

This change or one of its cross-repo dependencies was unable to be automatically merged with the current state of its repository. Please rebase the change and upload a new patchset.'}, {'account_id': 17156, 'date': '2016-01-10 18:22:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 27:

Just a quick Update:

We've discussed this with Clay, it can be seen here:
https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/swift_symlink_post_strategy

What I believe we've concluded is in POST AS COPY scenarios, that flowing over the POST from the symlink to the target object is no worse than a regular POST (ignoring symlinks).  That is to say it's not great and inconsistency from the user's order of operation is indeed possible.  But again, the potential hole in symlink is not worse and the consequences are comparable.

So I think we are Ok with that behaviour.

Now the problem is FAST-POST handling, I do believe the behaviour for the *** existing *** FAST-POST handling and symlink POSTing may be worse than posting a regular object.

We are investingating the above now to see if this is indeed the case and if it is what changes we can make to improve the situation.

The end goal is to flow over the POST to the target option, as this is by far and large the desired behaviour !

More soon"}, {'account_id': 9625, 'date': '2016-05-20 18:01:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 28.'}, {'account_id': 9625, 'date': '2016-05-20 18:02:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 28:

I just started looking.  haven't made my way through the mw yet.  comments below, plus I remember a convo on irc about functests being skipped if using post-as-copy so they dont fail.  But when I run without symlinks in my pipeline and have post-as-copy, i get several failures.  Is symlinks going to be a required mw?  If so, then it should be auto-inserted."}, {'account_id': 12279, 'date': '2016-11-03 01:57:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 40:

(1 comment)

sorry I didn't look far into these errors before.  Just a couple easy things to fix.  One, skip the symlink tests if it is not in the pipeline. The other is about the ordering when having crypto in the pipeline as well."}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2016-11-03 15:46:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 40:

We discussed the merge plan for this at the summit and in yesterday's meeting. Here's the plan.

First, Thiago and Janie will get this into shape where they are happy with it (like normal reviews). At that point, the rest of the cores will take a look with a specific eye to API design. When we've got a consensus, we'll land it. From a logistics perspective, this will take a community-wide focus, like we do near releases and to land feature branches."}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2016-11-04 17:08:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 40:

can we get started on the API docs sooner rather than later?  Maybe it's no so good to wait until it's "finished" to get more eyes on it?

I think the idea is "it's getting close" - so if they're starting to think there's no huge gaping architecture issues that need to be worked out - it could be a good time to pause and look at the broader picture before trying to polish it up?

Nice work all!'}, {'account_id': 12279, 'date': '2016-11-07 02:52:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 40:

(6 comments)

I still need to go over the tests and run tests.  But first, I would like to better understand the intended behavior of POSTs (see questions below).

Also, auto-tiering would be a different piece of middleware, correct?  We have talked about auto-tiering being a consumer of symlinks, but that middleware would handle things differently in that POSTs and DELETEs would apply to the symlink.  I'd like to better understand how these two fit together.  The interaction between these different use cases may need to be considered when reviewing the documentation in this patch."}, {'account_id': 12279, 'date': '2016-11-10 19:44:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 40:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 12279, 'date': '2016-11-11 21:45:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 40:

(3 comments)

(1 comment)

Thanks for the rework, Thiago!  I am still looking at the description and behaviors.  I have been putting together the api docs, and was testing what happens with different requests.

One test case that stuck out to me is the one where a user might 1) attempt to change the symlink target path.  and 2) attempt to create a symlink out of an existing zero-size object.

Results were:
1) That target path can never change.  But user-meta that existed on the symlink is removed.
2) The POST to add the symlink header will be successful and create a symlink.  But user-meta is removed, and the response is the redirect.
note that user-meta given at the same time as the symlink header is preserved.
Is the user-meta namespace replaced when a symlink header is successfully processed?

to see these results and the curl commands, see http://paste.openstack.org/show/591013/'}, {'account_id': 9625, 'date': '2016-12-06 18:28:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 42:

(1 comment)

@Janie, thanks for looking over the code. I think you found an inconsistency with it. At some point we had decided that users can only set a symlink target header (i.e., create a symlink) with a PUT, POSTs requests would not be allowed, but what you found is an inconsistency between fast-post and post_as_copy modes. 

In the case of your test #1, you are seeing that result correctly with either fast-post or post-as-copy (with the caveat that user-meta is removed). With fast-post, because in the post handling we never change the header to a sysmeta, so it just gets dropped. In the case of post_as_copy, _check_symlink_header(req) copies the sysmeta (old) header over the new header.

In your test #2, that only happens with post_as_copy and that's because by the time the request arrives at symlink middleware, it has become a PUT request and since the source did not have the sysmeta header (as in test #1), _check_symlink_header(req) won't catch it.

My suggestion is that we actually block the POST request (when it contains a X-Symlink-Target header) before it is even sent to the object server. This way we can better document the API, return a fast error for users and also users would not lose any user-meta in case they sent the request by mistake."}, {'account_id': 9625, 'date': '2016-12-06 21:45:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 43.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-12-06 23:13:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 43: Verified+1

(6 comments)

I haven't reviewed this; but in looking at the API and thinking about interactions with the rest of the system I came up with a few things that I want to check (unless you're sure they're broken in which case... tests?)

a POST to a symlink with with ?symlink=true need not 3XX - the intent was explicit and clear - 202 FTW.

a GET response that ends up traversing symlinks should include the name of the final location that is the canonical source of the data (probably in Content-Location header)

Conditional Requests (If-Match, If-Modified, etc) should be documented to affect *the final target object* (not the symlink) N.B. this will probably require teach the object server to *not* do conditional responses when it finds x-object-sysmeta-symlink-target-object metadata.

Container-Sync should only sync the symlinks not the targets - the way SLO's work is *insane* it accidentally leverages the fact that Static-Large-Object true is *not* sysmeta and then in the receiver it just allows it because it trusts the source.  If we go look a the reviews for that change it probably mentions symlinks and how ugly this will be to fix.

We should document the swift_source/middleware key for symlink subrequests (in the logging docs)

The ETag of a symlink should always be a zero-byte object - we can force that validation if we want (on disk or in the container listing).

Tim has an idea where we can append the x-symlink-target value (the whole path really, /a/c/o) into the "x-object-sysmeta-container-updater-override-etag" metadata of the object so that the container server/database will know this immutable value of the object (and mabye include it in the api-response someday; json can grow new keys pretty safely).  We should discuss this more.

tempurls to symlinks will follow their targets; but must honor the scoping of the tempurl key that created them (container tempurls only work w/i the conintainer; account tempurls only work w/i in the account).

You should not be able to create a symlink with a PUT tempurl [1]

Versioned Writes middleware on overwrite should copy the symlink (not the referenced target) - need to double check we're using symlink=true on the GET/COPY side of the overwrite protection requests in versioned writes middleware.

1. https://github.com/openstack/swift/blob/436374e66c21b1ea7974d5c10527e72eca47a738/swift/common/middleware/tempurl.py#L216'}, {'account_id': 12279, 'date': '2017-01-11 21:03:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 45.'}, {'account_id': 12279, 'date': '2017-01-11 22:02:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 46.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2017-01-11 23:09:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 46:

(11 comments)

I checked remaining functional tests.
I think there are many duplicated codes in functional tests for combination of symlink and other functions.
In my understanding, the duplication is for testing transparency of symlink.
If you want to test transparency of symlink, these combinative functional test classes should be subclasses of original functional test classes and tests should be implemented as same methods.
For example, functional test classes "TestSymlinkSlo" and "TestSymlinkToSloSegments" can be implemented as a subclass of "test.functional.test_slo.TestSlo".
My implementation image is <https://gist.github.com/KazuhiroMiyahara/8e433f7ff4640e7864b82eee17c36d2f>
I think this strategy can be applied to other combinative functional test classes, TestSyminkComparison, TestSymlinkAccountTempurl, TestSymlinkContainerTempurl, TestSymlinkVersioning.'}, {'account_id': 14766, 'date': '2017-04-10 09:30:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 53:

Remind me, where does the proxy-server conf come from for in-process func tests? I wonder if the post-as-copy test somehow didn't get symlink in its pipeline...

Not clear on why the DSVM test failed... I get that we apparently have an absolute location when we were expecting a relative one, but who did that translation? And why didn't it cause the *other* DSVM tests to fail?"}, {'account_id': 4608, 'date': '2017-09-11 19:59:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 56:

@Tim

Though I don't get the trick yet but it looks symlink appears in the dvsm config [1] so that symlink func tests ran and failed.

For reviewers, the reason why a test failed with dsvm gate is authtoken middleware for keystone auth translates the location header from relative path to absolute path in webob wsgify [1] that is maintained in the out of our repo.

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 4608, 'date': '2017-10-05 09:04:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 59: Code-Review-1

(6 comments)

I was walking through almost of the main logic on the symlink and push some extra comments on that. (sorry not checked out the test code so much)

-1 because I didn't get some design decision on the following cases, A) Symlink in the internal client pipeline, B) symlink info in container listing

About item A, it looks like symlink is only one "API extension" middleware and I didn't get why we need it into there. Perhaps, it's because container-sync could have issue on that. However, the similar staffs like slo doesn't so it seems inconsistent and we should discuss where (in container-sync? in pipeline) we should resolve the issue. Sorry I didn't get WHAT IS THE ISSUE  too yet.

About item B, I didn't get why we have to mangle the hash space with symlink target info in the container listing. It seems a bunch of code affected the specification. e.g. SymlinkContainerContext is created only for the converting the listing result,  another example is that symlink content length is required to be 0 because we have to update override etag with empty content md5 + symlink info.

Perhaps, those have been already discussed in the past meeting, ptg, hackathon, and summit, though.'}, {'account_id': 14766, 'date': '2017-10-05 11:25:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 59: -Code-Review

(3 comments)

Fix small bugs I found. I'm sure the symlink has had long history of development.

There are several design discussions in the history and those all are resolved.

This patch includes new feature symlink. The specification is well documented. Unit tests cover 100% branches. Functional tests cover a bunch of combination cases with other middlewares.  Those are awesome. I'm pretty sure this version is the best in the patch series.

Thanks all contributors for the effort to build this functionality."}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2017-12-07 23:42:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 75:

I think there is an issue with restore/copy of a symlink using PUT/x-copy-from [1]

Specifically the copy middleware makes special care to transfer a multipart-manifest=get query string param from the PUT request to the GET request and we should do the same for symlink=get [1]

N.B. COPY of symlink w/ symlink=get already works

1. https://gist.github.com/clayg/a883d21723bda1a947109be2d33e2be2
2. https://gist.github.com/clayg/95cc8f0ecdbec1ee2c85afa0f134507a'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2017-12-13 05:43:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 76: Code-Review+2

I was mistaken about the behavior of PUT + X-Copy-From - it works the same as COPY + Destination - as long as you provide symlink=get qs to the PUT or COPY request URI the *symlink* is copied (not the target object)

Please disregard my earlier comment - I was wrong.

I pushed some follow-on functests [1] which should pass with out any other changes and prove the correctness of symlink COPY behavior (as well as functionally cover symlinks + versioned writes)

1. https://review.openstack.org/527583'}, {'account_id': 4608, 'date': '2017-12-13 06:22:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 77.'}, {'account_id': 4608, 'date': '2017-12-13 06:29:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 77:

Just merge conflict resolved. Sorry Clay, I banished your valuable +2 with this rebasing...'}, {'account_id': 4608, 'date': '2017-12-13 07:53:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 78.'}, {'account_id': 4608, 'date': '2017-12-13 08:10:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 78: Code-Review+2

(3 comments)

This patch progressed really for a past week.

- The conditional response issue resolved. 
- The problem with container-sync (cross-account) resolved.
- Various tests added.

we still have follow ups:
- https://review.openstack.org/#/c/527475 (docs from Alistair)
- https://review.openstack.org/#/c/527583 (functests symlink+vw from Clay)
- https://review.openstack.org/#/c/527595 (unit tests symlink + copy more from me)

those are worth but I don't think those are blockers to land this.

One possible discussion remaining at https://review.openstack.org/#/c/527126/ that attempts to add symlink into container-sync internal client pipeline. However, IMO, we can change the configurable option LATER because the default behavior with this patch is that symlink works as expected (i.e. transfer symlink object as symlink) without extra operator's steps. Even if it would be changed latter, it won't be a migration issue anyway.

Because of those reasons, I'm sure this is nice version to have so keep my +2 score for now."}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2017-12-13 10:33:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 78:

(5 comments)

Great work everybody.

I think it would be best to decide on the container-sync issue [1] now, before this merges. Otherwise, it becomes a future upgrade issue:

This patchset:

* op upgrades swift and gets symlink support
* op deploys new config to enable symlinks; op does not configure internal-client for container-sync (as per this patchset)
* subesequently [1] is merged
* swift upgrade will break container-sync/symlinks unless container-sync config is changed

vs, with [1]:

* op upgrades swift and gets symlink support
* op deploys new config to enable symlinks; op configures internal-client for container-sync (as per [1])

The nit comments below are all addressed in my follow-on patch [2] and IMHO do *not* need to be fixed before this patch merges.


[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/527126
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/527475'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2017-12-13 17:16:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 78: Code-Review+1

I think https://review.openstack.org/#/c/527126/ would be good to squash to simplify ... hopefully we can make a decision about that at the meeting today.'}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2017-12-13 21:41:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 79.'}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2017-12-13 23:05:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 79:

squashed in https://review.openstack.org/#/c/527126/3'}, {'account_id': 4608, 'date': '2017-12-14 01:13:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 79: Code-Review+2

(7 comments)

I'm still keep my +2. the change from my last +2 is awesome by Alistair. there are just small nits tho, it looks reasonable, and tested well to me. I think we had a lot of eyes to review in the history and even in recent, Clay and Alistair and I reviewed/wrote something together so any core can push the door to add +A. Hopefully, Clay and Alistair would take a look again tho.

I hope, third time's a charm, this is my third +2. Thanks all. And I'll keep my concentration on the follow ups and cleanup more docs."}, {'account_id': 14766, 'date': '2017-12-14 05:17:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 79: Code-Review+1

'}, {'created': '2016-08-29 19:35:43.000000000', 'message': 'Symlink implementation.

Add a symbolic link ("symlink") object support to Swift. This
object will reference another object. GET and HEAD
requests for a symlink object will operate on the referenced object.
DELETE and PUT requests for a symlink object will operate on the
symlink object, not the referenced object, and will delete or
overwrite it, respectively.
POST requests are *not* forwarded to the referenced object and should
be sent directly. POST requests sent to a symlink object will
result in a 307 Error.

Historical information on symlink design can be found here:
https://github.com/openstack/swift-specs/blob/master/specs/in_progress/symlinks.rst.
https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/swift_symlinks

Change-Id: I838ed71bacb3e33916db8dd42c7880d5bb9f8e18
Signed-off-by: Thiago da Silva <thiago@redhat.com>

'}, {'created': '2017-09-19 23:54:23.000000000', 'message': 'Symlink implementation.

Add a symbolic link ("symlink") object support to Swift. This
object will reference another object. GET and HEAD
requests for a symlink object will operate on the referenced object.
DELETE and PUT requests for a symlink object will operate on the
symlink object, not the referenced object, and will delete or
overwrite it, respectively.
POST requests are *not* forwarded to the referenced object and should
be sent directly. POST requests sent to a symlink object will
result in a 307 Error.

Historical information on symlink design can be found here:
https://github.com/openstack/swift-specs/blob/master/specs/in_progress/symlinks.rst.
https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/swift_symlinks

commit_message:
Symlink implementation.

Add a symbolic link ("symlink") object support to Swift. This
object will reference another object. GET and HEAD
requests for a symlink object will operate on the referenced object.
DELETE and PUT requests for a symlink object will operate on the
symlink object, not the referenced object, and will delete or
overwrite it, respectively.
POST requests are *not* forwarded to the referenced object and should
be sent directly. POST requests sent to a symlink object will
result in a 307 Error.

Historical information on symlink design can be found here:
https://github.com/openstack/swift-specs/blob/master/specs/in_progress/symlinks.rst.
https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/swift_symlinks

Co-Authored-By: Thiago da Silva <thiago@redhat.com>
Co-Authored-By: Janie Richling <jrichli@us.ibm.com>

Co-Authored-By: Kota Tsuyuzaki <tsuyuzaki.kota@lab.ntt.co.jp>

commit_message:
Change the galera health check for better cluster health

The current galera cluster health check simply logs into a cluster node
but does not check if the node is sync'd. This can lead to an issue
where a node is placed back into the pool before it is ready. If this
happens it can lead to a broken OpenStack environment until the wsrep
received queue is processed which is especially true if the node out of
sync happens to be the primary.

Combined backport of:
- https://review.openstack.org/520673
- https://review.openstack.org/523854
- https://review.openstack.org/524107

Closes-Bug: #1665667
Change-Id: I49e371a2743618a0b5544a23e892aa28bb8567eb
Depends-On: I81c924464aa4b19c2a62f37b5bf26c3c0453786a
Depends-On: Ie1b3b9724dd33de1d90634166e585ecceb1f4c96
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
(cherry picked from commit 8c0ce1c62f73f880ed255b20ea932852288d23e9)

[{'created': '2017-12-14 02:24:12.000000000', 'message': "Retry _trait_sync on deadlock

We're seeing DBDeadlock failures during scheduling in CI jobs
when syncing traits when getting allocation candidates.

We have a lock around this code but that's not going to carry across
multiple processes, so we need to be able to retry on deadlock if

Closes-Bug: #1738083

commit_message:
Retry _trait_sync on deadlock

We're seeing DBDeadlock failures during scheduling in CI jobs
when syncing traits when getting allocation candidates.

We have a lock around this code but that's not going to carry across
multiple processes, so we need to be able to retry on deadlock if
one occurs.

Change-Id: I6cf1793c1cbed18d850ec7e32b5b195e78cb4e68
Closes-Bug: #1738083

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-11-21 04:21:09.000000000', 'message': 'Fix Horizon asset compression not happening on redeploy

A recent change to kolla-ansible (a729dcc4) bind mounts /tmp from the
host to handle uploading of larger images. Unfortunately this is also
where we keep the state file for horizon which controls whether assets
need to be recompressed (.local_settings.md5sum.txt). This means it is
left over on destroy and causes issues with CSS / assets on redeploy.

Change the location of this file to
/var/lib/kolla/.local_settings.md5sum.txt so it is cleaned up correctly
along with the container.

Change-Id: Icfc71266cabedc2c1a3d30590cada3f774bc0d2c
Closes-Bug: #1721281
(cherry picked from commit cad0a1e697ebc2caf9dd9dc6e4abe6ccaccf1b07)

need to be recompressed (.local_settings.md5sum.txt). This means it is
left over on destroy and causes issues with CSS / assets on redeploy.

Change the location of this file to
/var/lib/kolla/.local_settings.md5sum.txt so it is cleaned up correctly

Change-Id: Icfc71266cabedc2c1a3d30590cada3f774bc0d2c
Closes-Bug: #1721281
(cherry picked from commit cad0a1e697ebc2caf9dd9dc6e4abe6ccaccf1b07)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix Horizon asset compression not happening on redeploy

A recent change to kolla-ansible (a729dcc4) bind mounts /tmp from the
host to handle uploading of larger images. Unfortunately this is also
where we keep the state file for horizon which controls whether assets
need to be recompressed (.local_settings.md5sum.txt). This means it is
left over on destroy and causes issues with CSS / assets on redeploy.

Change the location of this file to
/var/lib/kolla/.local_settings.md5sum.txt so it is cleaned up correctly
along with the container.

Change-Id: Icfc71266cabedc2c1a3d30590cada3f774bc0d2c
Closes-Bug: #1721281
(cherry picked from commit cad0a1e697ebc2caf9dd9dc6e4abe6ccaccf1b07)

commit_message:
Use addClassResourceCleanup in test_inherits

This is to replace resource_cleanup with addClassResourceCleanup
in test_inherits, with this we will have finished all the
resource_cleanups in identity testcases.

Change-Id: I1b416c3af3c585274f1f88f6f740dcc0fbfee15d

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-03-30 03:56:08.000000000', 'message': "XenAPI: Don't use nicira-iface-id for XenServer VIF

When using neutron polling mode, we found after reboot, the VM cannot
ping anymore. After investigation we found we set vif['id'](i.e. neutron
port uuid from neutron's perspective of view) to two different OVS ports.
One is the xenserver VIF, the other is tap device qvo-XXXX which neutron
ovs agent will monitor and deal with.
This patch is to deprecate the setting of 'nicira-iface-id' (which will
result in 'iface-id' in ovsdb) in XAPI DB and use 'neutron-port-id', so
next release, we can remove 'nicira-iface-id'.
Note: There is no problem if we don't use neutron-ovs-agent polling mode

Change-Id: I221e89686c8e9041651f5affc4e3542d75ff55bc

"}, {'created': '2017-11-16 08:27:20.000000000', 'message': 'XenAPI: Don't use nicira-iface-id for XenServer VIF

When using neutron polling mode, we found VM cannot ping any more
after reboot manually (not from CLI or GUI). This is because we set
vif['id'](i.e. neutron port uuid) to XenServer VIF. When reboot VM,
as neutron use "ovsdb-client monitor" to monitor the port changes,
it will thought the port is deleted as booting VM will result in
deleting and creating VIF in XenServer side.
But actually, this isn't true, the real tap-xxx port isn't deleted
as we just reboot VM. But neutron cannot monitor the creating of
VIF because the VM's reboot isn't trigger via OpenStack CLI.
This patch is to delete the usage of 'nicira-iface-id' in XAPI DB
and use 'neutron-port-id' insteady as we have already deprecated
'nicira-iface-id' in Pike release.

Closes-Bug: #1732624

Change-Id: I221e89686c8e9041651f5affc4e3542d75ff55bc
'}, {'created': '2017-11-27 06:11:42.000000000', 'message': 'XenAPI: Don't use nicira-iface-id for XenServer VIF

When using neutron polling mode, we found VM cannot ping any more
after reboot manually (not from CLI or GUI). This is because we set
vif['id'](i.e. neutron port uuid) to XenServer VIF's other_config
with key 'nicira-iface-id'.
When reboot VM, as neutron use "ovsdb-client monitor" to monitor
the port changes, it will thought the port is deleted as booting
VM will result in deleting and creating VIF in XenServer side.
But actually, this isn't true, the real tap-xxx port isn't deleted
as we just reboot VM. But neutron cannot monitor the creating of
VIF because the VM's reboot isn't trigger via OpenStack CLI.
This patch is to delete the usage of 'nicira-iface-id' and use
'neutron-port-id' insteady as we have already deprecated
'nicira-iface-id' in Pike release.

Closes-Bug: #1732624

Change-Id: I221e89686c8e9041651f5affc4e3542d75ff55bc

commit_message:
XenAPI: Don't use nicira-iface-id for XenServer VIF

When using neutron polling mode, booting a VM will timeout because
nova-compute cannot receive network-vif-plugged event. This is
because we set vif['id'](i.e. neutron port uuid) to two different
OVS ports. One is Xenserver VIF, the other is tap device qvo-XXXX
which neutron ovs agent will monitor and deal with.
My previous patch https://review.openstack.org/#/c/463246/ has
deprecated the setting of 'nicira-iface-id' to XenServer. This
patch is to remove the setting of 'nicira-iface-id'.

Closes-Bug: #1732624

Change-Id: I221e89686c8e9041651f5affc4e3542d75ff55bc

commit_message:
Use native npm lint/test jobs

We can use now the Zuul v3 native jobs for the npm lint and test jobs.
Replace legacy jobs.

Also, add these jobs for neutron-lbaas-dashboard and octavia-dashboard
so that we can remove the legacy jobs from in-tree - these npm jobs are
mandated, so should life in project-config.

Change-Id: I80dea47f0ba43f74e074ba61b465e3f7d4f28952
Needed-By: Iaa12d48041aa0ac4b3432061f5f4079bac69f16f
Needed-By: I63924c40b2becf13915e0a3d6475a613de0c2181
Needed-By: Ic876453ffe8cd5cbfa89ba99b9f257683ca595c1

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-12-13 23:57:11.000000000', 'message': 'puppet-beaker tests: don't use puppet 4

The original job code was doing a "if {node} == ubuntu-xenial".  This
got expanded out by the autoconversion, but because it uses "==" with
"[" and runs under POSIX shell (rather than bash) this just ends up as
a syntax error.

Since the test is a no-op in most cases, remove it to avoid the error.
Also use /bin/bash for the cmd for sanity.

This also makes the Xenial tests just use puppet3, which is the puppet
included with Xenial.  This is becoming an issue because infra is
updating to Xenial nodes now, so we are using this against some of our
puppet modules, but only targetting puppet3.

Change-Id: I2355cf58c899bf5f78173b2ed9da26548a9592d0
'}]
commit_message:
puppet-beaker tests: don't use puppet 4

The original job code was doing a "if {node} == ubuntu-xenial".  This
got expanded out by the autoconversion, but because it uses "==" with
"[" and runs under POSIX shell (rather than bash) this just ends up as
a syntax error.

Since the test is a no-op in most cases, remove it to avoid the error.
Also use /bin/bash for the cmd for sanity.

This also makes the Xenial tests just use puppet3, which is the puppet
included with Xenial.  This is becoming an issue because infra is
updating to Xenial nodes now, so we are using this against some of our
puppet modules, but only targetting puppet3.

Change-Id: I2355cf58c899bf5f78173b2ed9da26548a9592d0

subject: Fix DNS connectivity issues with DVR+HA routers and DHCP-HA
messages: [{'account_id': 748, 'date': '2017-12-14 16:55:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 1131, 'date': '2017-12-14 19:05:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 4694, 'date': '2017-12-14 19:11:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2017-12-14 16:55:10.000000000', 'message': "Fix DNS connectivity issues with DVR+HA routers and DHCP-HA

Before this change, DVR_SNAT agents would get no routers when
asking for updates due to provisioning of DHCP ports on the
node they are running on. This means that there's no connectivity
between the DHCP port and the network gateway (that may be
hosted on a different node), and therefore things like DNS may
break when a VM attempts resolution when talking to the affected
DHCP port.

This change relaxed a conditional that prevents the right list of
routers to be compiled and returned from the server to the agent.
The agent on the other hand needs to make sure to allocate the
right type of router based on what is being returned from the server.

Closes-bug: #1733987

Change-Id: I6124738c3324e0cc3f7998e3a541ff7547f2a8a7
(cherry picked from commit b24013f569024f71197370b10dd23a7647d22c73)
(cherry picked from commit cd4527733767721f1d5198536a79b3a24d5d1fea)
"}]
commit_message:
Fix DNS connectivity issues with DVR+HA routers and DHCP-HA

Before this change, DVR_SNAT agents would get no routers when
asking for updates due to provisioning of DHCP ports on the
node they are running on. This means that there's no connectivity
between the DHCP port and the network gateway (that may be
hosted on a different node), and therefore things like DNS may
break when a VM attempts resolution when talking to the affected
DHCP port.

This change relaxed a conditional that prevents the right list of
routers to be compiled and returned from the server to the agent.
The agent on the other hand needs to make sure to allocate the
right type of router based on what is being returned from the server.

Closes-bug: #1733987

Change-Id: I6124738c3324e0cc3f7998e3a541ff7547f2a8a7
(cherry picked from commit b24013f569024f71197370b10dd23a7647d22c73)
(cherry picked from commit cd4527733767721f1d5198536a79b3a24d5d1fea)

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
    Workflow: http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
    Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 23630, 'date': '2017-12-11 08:45:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

commit_message:
Remove the ceilometer api dockerfile

1. Ceilometer API has been deprecated since Ocata release,
this patch to remove it for kolla
2. move the extend_start.sh into eilometer-notification

Change-Id: Iea0a46aead14e238fe102d4127b7774dbc2be0e4

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-12-12 16:03:44.000000000', 'message': 'Wait for live_migration_rollback.start notification

The test_live_migration_abort step of the test_migration_actions
notification sample test could randomly fail on the number of
notification received. This happens becuase the test only waits for
the live_migration_abort notification but then expect that also
the live_migration_rollback notification is received. However the
rollback notification is emited after the abort which sometimes
makes the test fast enough to miss that.

The patch adds an explicit wait for the rollback notification to
stabilize the test

Change-Id: I70d8f661fa75e7688e7e3cd527c9d1ee7415c50b
Closes-Bug: #1737781
'}, {'created': '2017-12-13 14:34:03.000000000', 'message': 'Wait for live_migration_rollback.end notification

The test_live_migration_abort step of the test_migration_actions
notification sample test could randomly fail on the number of
notification received. This happens becuase the test only waits for
the live_migration_abort notification but then expect that also
the live_migration_rollback notification is received. However the
rollback notification is emited after the abort which sometimes
makes the test fast enough to miss that.

The patch adds an explicit wait for the rollback notification to
stabilize the test

Change-Id: I70d8f661fa75e7688e7e3cd527c9d1ee7415c50b
Closes-Bug: #1737781
'}]
commit_message:
Wait for live_migration_rollback.end notification

The test_live_migration_abort step of the test_migration_actions
notification sample test could randomly fail on the number of
notification received. This happens becuase the test only waits for
the live_migration_abort notification but then expect that also
the live_migration_rollback notification is received. However the
rollback notification is emited after the abort which sometimes
makes the test fast enough to miss that.

The patch adds an explicit wait for the rollback notification to
stabilize the test

Change-Id: I70d8f661fa75e7688e7e3cd527c9d1ee7415c50b
Closes-Bug: #1737781

commit_message:
Handle exception on adding secgroup

If user adds security group to an instance and the instance already
has that security group, neutron will return a 400 response. Nova
should handle the 400 response properly. In before, Nova doesn't
seem to handle this case and end-user gets a 500 response. This
commit fixed it.

Conflicts:
      nova/network/security_group/neutron_driver.py

NOTE(hongbin): The conflict is due to the removal of translation of
log messages.

Closes-Bug: #1691274
Change-Id: I58b19ef6b537d690df90e542b6af3c64773ecc87
(cherry picked from commit 083bc89f99e007c400b9f89c63ac0459da910df8)

Add dns-integration setup to devstack plugin

This will be used in a job that will run neutron designate integration
tests from the neutron-tempest-plugin repo.

commit_message:
Add decorator to mark unstable tests

As is done in the neutron repo, add a decorator to mark
tests as unstable so that we can work in parallel on
fixing them while having the job pass.

Mark the DVR east-west tests as unstable to prove it works.

Change-Id: I15fcdcba681d40c96f9f79aaa21881bc45fe3066
Related-bug: #1717302

commit_message:
Fix URL in SR-IOV internals doc

The last link in the 'Further Reading' section of the SR-IOV internals
document is not rendered properly. It gets a '/' at the end, that
makes the link useless. It seems to be a problem with Sphinx. To
work around it, the bullets are removed from the list of recommended
documents for further reading

Closes-Bug: #1737833

Change-Id: I2116e82d60bc361583eab8e3809ec5f9eab6d11c

supported

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-12-05 16:46:59.000000000', 'message': 'Make discovery use dnsmasq dhcp filter

plugin.sh now recognizes additional dnsmasq pxe filter configuration
options:

  IRONIC_INSPECTOR_DHCP_HOSTSDIR
  IRONIC_INSPECTOR_DNSMASQ_START_COMMAND
  IRONIC_INSPECTOR_DNSMASQ_STOP_COMMAND

and configures both the inspector and dnsmasq accordingly.

The playbooks/legacy/ironic-inspector-tempest-dsvm-discovery/run.yaml now
executes with dnsmasq pxe filter driver.

commit_message:
Make discovery use dnsmasq dhcp filter

plugin.sh now recognizes additional dnsmasq pxe filter configuration
options:

  IRONIC_INSPECTOR_DHCP_HOSTSDIR
  IRONIC_INSPECTOR_DNSMASQ_START_COMMAND
  IRONIC_INSPECTOR_DNSMASQ_STOP_COMMAND

and configures both the inspector and dnsmasq accordingly.

The playbooks/legacy/ironic-inspector-tempest-dsvm-discovery/run.yaml now
executes with dnsmasq pxe filter driver.

The inspector_iniset function was updated to be able to set option values
consisting of multiple words.

Change-Id: Ib0879e0045e28ae778d2de6c1b5cd23f5fafda17

commit_message:
fix dvsm config deprecations

The [firewall] group was deprecated but our devstack still uses it.  This
patch replaces the IRONIC_INSPECTOR_MANAGE_FIREWALL=True/False variable
with an IRONIC_INSPECTOR_DHCP_FILTER variable with a default of 'iptables'
and sets the [pxe_filter]driver config value. The
IRONIC_INSPECTOR_INTERFACE is now set in the [iptables] config section.

Change-Id: Icf6fe6c6a98ab815edefe3c0e1ec3ce9a064bf2e

Thanks Dmitry! I've got some comments inline.

Also, I was wondering if you wanted to update these pages:

https://github.com/openstack/ironic/blob/master/doc/source/install/configure-ipmi.rst:
- first paragraph, do we want to delete pxe_ipmitool & agent_ipmitool?
- "Collecting sensor data" section; there is mention of "such as drivers ending with ipmitool", do we want to remove/reword to 'ipmi' hardware type?

https://github.com/openstack/ironic/blob/master/doc/source/install/configure-glance-swift.rst:
- first line, "in particular, any agent_* drivers" ? If nothing else, change the order to have hardware types first?

I don't feel strongly about any of this; wanted to pass it by you though.'}, {'account_id': 6637, 'date': '2017-12-13 11:56:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

commit_message:
Switch emphasis to hardware types in the installation guide

This change updates the installation guide to talk in terms of hardware types
and hardware interfaces, only briefly mentioning classic drivers, when needed.

Also fixes incorrect information about instance_info fields in the standalone
guide.

Change-Id: I5e8a0de79c247535fd599318540fb8bbd2fc5df0

commit_message:
Use the tempest plugin from openstack/ironic-tempest-plugin

Follow-on patch will delete the
openstack/ironic/ironic_tempest_plugin/ directory. But this will need
to be done after this patch has been backported to the stable
branches, otherwise the stable branches will break.

Change-Id: I31bb088679ea122efaa91d362e613edb74c14254

commit_message:
Use the tempest plugin from openstack/ironic-tempest-plugin

Follow-on patch will delete the
openstack/ironic-inspector/ironic_inspector/test/inspector_tempest_plugin/
directory. But this will need to be done after this patch has been
backported to the stable branches, otherwise the stable branches will
break.

Change-Id: I94b74aa83e6898a11f6b81862325cee395a0fd3e
Depends-On: I4fb07ecad151421f2aa132394e048a9fce67f7b4

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-10-09 13:33:03.000000000', 'message': 'expand type documentation for Enforcer arguments

As part of bug #1720354 we discovered that arguments being passed to
the enforcer were not always dictionaries and did not always support
the full API needed. Expand the documentation to make the requirements
clearer.

Change-Id: I6c940d825cf72777e2a7946ab7489a1ed5359235
Closes-Bug: #1720354
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
'}]
commit_message:
expand type documentation for Enforcer arguments

As part of bug #1720354 we discovered that arguments being passed to
the enforcer were not always dictionaries and did not always support
the full API needed. Expand the documentation to make the requirements
clearer.

Change-Id: I6c940d825cf72777e2a7946ab7489a1ed5359235
Closes-Bug: #1720354
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
Fix requirements building

We were not failing when wheels failed to build. Implement a quick fix
for that issue

Change-Id: I934beb526caca90db93c01c8ec5ac9dd63d6ddc9

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-12-04 21:11:49.000000000', 'message': "Clean-up zuul.d/ files

Create a new base job: legacy-ipa-dsvm-base

Define 'irrelevant-files' in legacy-ipa-dsvm-base and remove them from
project.yaml. This means we only define 'irrelevant-files' once. Also
makes project.yaml much easier to read.

Fix the 'irrelevant-files' section to make sure we do test
when changes to 'requirements.txt'.

Remove the 'branches:' section from the experimental job
'ipa-tempest-dsvm-partition-pxe_ipmitool-tinyipa-python3'

Sort the jobs lists in project.yaml.

Change-Id: Idbace38e0558e8a80e2d405ea0f6a0698989e140
(cherry picked from commit 8ba851bf27918319fdc174f495d971857fb356e0)
"}]
commit_message:
Clean-up zuul.d/ files

Create a new base job: legacy-ipa-dsvm-base

Define 'irrelevant-files' in legacy-ipa-dsvm-base and remove them from
project.yaml. This means we only define 'irrelevant-files' once. Also
makes project.yaml much easier to read.

Fix the 'irrelevant-files' section to make sure we do test
when changes to 'requirements.txt'.

Remove the 'branches:' section from the experimental job

[{'created': '2017-09-27 13:42:59.000000000', 'message': 'Report /dev/disk/by-path on inspection followup

This is the followup patch for
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/498489 fixing the issues
not covered initially.

Most importantly, this change makes tests that depends
on ironic-lib support dependent on ironic-lib version
available at the testing time.
Specifically, this change is required for those
conditional tests to run:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/500524/

'}, {'created': '2017-09-27 14:39:12.000000000', 'message': 'Report /dev/disk/by-path on inspection followup

This is the followup patch for
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/498489 fixing issues
with the unit tests not addressed initially.

Most importantly, this change makes tests that depends
on ironic-lib support dependent on ironic-lib version
available at the testing time.

commit_message:
Add swift_store_large_object_chunk_size parameter

Add a new parameter to swift backend to let user set the chunk size when
glance will start chunking the images before uploading.

Change-Id: I9984bdb416ec9d874345b410557ef42c360232fb
Signed-off-by: Arnaud Morin <arnaud.morin@corp.ovh.com>
(cherry picked from commit 2ce1ddfd83361d51228720ff1116020a98b5e949)

commit_message:
Clean up zuul files

Changes to legacy-bifrost-jobs.yaml:
- creates two jobs:
  - bifrost-base
  - bifrost-integration
- adds 'irrelevant-files' section to bifrost-base (from project.yaml)
  as well as additional irrelevant files

Changes to project.yaml:
- moves 'irrelevant-files' section to legacy-bifrost-jobs.yaml
- sorts the jobs list; voting first, alphabetical; non-voting second

Conflicts:
  zuul.d/legacy-bifrost-jobs.yaml
  zuul.d/project.yaml

Change-Id: I514e7e40ecb95580a47922b253d8046cfcd1634c
(cherry picked from commit 12e6570bba850c83dd0b081cd24cb75d8d3247d9)

For node specific hiera data to work the machine unique UUID must
be in the Ironic database. However it's possible it will be missing

commit_message:
Node specific hiera data doc should mention inspection_extras

For node specific hiera data to work the machine unique UUID must
be in the Ironic database. However it's possible it will be missing
unless the undercloud is configured to collect it during
introspection. This change adds a sentence pointing out that this
could happen so the reader knows what to do if the machine unique
UUID is missing.

Change-Id: I754845be0a9c64fc5f7e9f6b3ec94d7bdab870b2

commit_message:
Fix issue with double mocking of utils.execute functions

An issue was discovered if we mock an already mock-ed function. This
was happening in our execute() detection code. Change it to not use a
mock and instead a function.

Add test cases to ensure it works as expected.

Change-Id: If58071b41c7e69bc182ea033bf647924f996f1f3

subject: Ceilometer newton-eol, cap keystonemiddleware
messages:
[{'account_id': 10311, 'date': '2017-12-14 01:52:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10311, 'date': '2017-12-14 01:54:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

Yeah, need this for Pike too.'}, {'account_id': 7052, 'date': '2017-12-14 05:56:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck no bug'}, {'account_id': 10311, 'date': '2017-12-14 16:35:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

It looks to be trying to pick up a newer version of monasca-api, which in turn is picking up a version of keystonemiddleware which now depends on memcache, and the tox tests are failing to find memcache.
There are a couple of different approaches, and some commits have been proposed to address this (such as https://review.openstack.org/#/c/526751/).  So we may have to cap a version to get around this.'}, {'account_id': 10311, 'date': '2017-12-14 17:15:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 7052, 'date': '2017-12-14 18:00:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2017-12-14 01:52:13.000000000', 'message': "Ceilometer newton-eol

Change the test-requirements to use the newton-eol branch, as
the stable/newton branch no longer exists in Ceilometer.
Also limit the oslotest to < 2.0.0 to avoid a mockpatch issue
in ceilometer's db.py unit test.

Note this change should soon be replaced by a move to Pike, but
want to update this as a solid starting point before further work.

Change-Id: I06b860bb72c3397e276311bd57291e9c3164a7e4
"}, {'created': '2017-12-14 17:15:44.000000000', 'message': "Ceilometer newton-eol, cap keystonemiddleware

Change the test-requirements to use the newton-eol branch, as
the stable/newton branch no longer exists in Ceilometer.
Also limit the oslotest to < 2.0.0 to avoid a mockpatch issue
in ceilometer's db.py unit test.

Note this change should soon be replaced by a move to Pike, but
want to update this as a solid starting point before further work.

Also capping keystonemiddleware to <= 4.17.0 (the Pike version).
A dependency on memcache has been added to keystone in Queens and
beyond, which earlier versions of ceilometer aren't set up to pull in.

Change-Id: I06b860bb72c3397e276311bd57291e9c3164a7e4
"}]
commit_message:
Ceilometer newton-eol, cap keystonemiddleware

Change the test-requirements to use the newton-eol branch, as
the stable/newton branch no longer exists in Ceilometer.
Also limit the oslotest to < 2.0.0 to avoid a mockpatch issue
in ceilometer's db.py unit test.

Note this change should soon be replaced by a move to Pike, but
want to update this as a solid starting point before further work.

Also capping keystonemiddleware to <= 4.17.0 (the Pike version).
A dependency on memcache has been added to keystone in Queens and
beyond, which earlier versions of ceilometer aren't set up to pull in.

Change-Id: I06b860bb72c3397e276311bd57291e9c3164a7e4

commit_message:
Fix use of iteritems in dnsmasq.conf templates.

iteritems() method is no longer exists in Python 3 dictionaries
which causes the neutron-openvswitch charm to throw an exception
if dnsmasq_flags option is set. Code has been changed to
items() method to work in Python 3.

Change-Id: I7eaae8f33ed0dc5c97ef478bfe9e1fbd7f79783f
Closes-Bug: #1738198

commit_message:
Add base jobs for functional tests

I keep copy-pasting these to projects from the shade repo. Let's make
some base jobs people can more easily use.

devstack-tox-functional runs devstack and a tox functional environment.

devstack-tox-functional-consumer is the same, but runs devstack in pre.
It's intended for projects for whom patches to the project won't
actually impact the devstack deployment (shade, nodepool, gophercloud
are all examples of such things)

Change-Id: I84de60181cb88574e341ff83cd4857cce241f2dd

commit_message:
Gate on v3 devstack job

The devstack base job in in use in many projects, but it is not being
gated here in devstack. Let's add it to the list so that we don't
accidentally break it.

Change-Id: Iea13235a8438d4b540f9f27b94aed13e719481dc

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-12-07 23:30:35.000000000', 'message': "Add regression test for rebuilding a volume-backed server

Commit 984dd8ad6add4523d93c7ce5a666a32233e02e34 makes rebuild
check to see if the user is rebuilding an instance with a new
image and if so, to run the scheduler filters again since the
new image might not work with the current host for the instance,
and we rebuild to the same host that the instance is already
running on.

The problem is the instance.image_ref attribute is not set for
a volume-backed (boot-from-volume) instance, so the conditional
in the rebuild() method is always True, which means we always run
through the scheduler for volume-backed instances during rebuild,
even if the image in the root disk isn't changing.

This adds a functional regression test to recreate the bug.

Conflicts:
      nova/tests/fixtures.py

NOTE(mriedem): The fixture conflict is due to not having the
CinderFixture in Newton. That was added in Ocata via commit
47fb8b757994688a995ec3bdfa5dccc72f870f34. It's added here in
it's entirety since that is simpler than trying to basically
re-write it from scratch in a backport.

NOTE(mriedem): The functional test is slightly modified to
not rely on Placement and because of old config option names.

Change-Id: If79c554b46c44a7f70f8367426e7da362d7234c8
Related-Bug: #1732947
(cherry picked from commit a4eebd5de7ef4b63082536718ba7b993a66d47e7)
(cherry picked from commit c7991653a4e7cbb86656e6ba7579a86236801567)
(cherry picked from commit fe5e3e7e61d879f7a28eb177e4bdbc7ead3ae4ac)
"}]
commit_message:
Add regression test for rebuilding a volume-backed server

Commit 984dd8ad6add4523d93c7ce5a666a32233e02e34 makes rebuild
check to see if the user is rebuilding an instance with a new
image and if so, to run the scheduler filters again since the
new image might not work with the current host for the instance,
and we rebuild to the same host that the instance is already
running on.

The problem is the instance.image_ref attribute is not set for
a volume-backed (boot-from-volume) instance, so the conditional
in the rebuild() method is always True, which means we always run
through the scheduler for volume-backed instances during rebuild,
even if the image in the root disk isn't changing.

This adds a functional regression test to recreate the bug.

Conflicts:
      nova/tests/fixtures.py

NOTE(mriedem): The fixture conflict is due to not having the
CinderFixture in Newton. That was added in Ocata via commit
47fb8b757994688a995ec3bdfa5dccc72f870f34. It's added here in
it's entirety since that is simpler than trying to basically
re-write it from scratch in a backport.

NOTE(mriedem): The functional test is slightly modified to
not rely on Placement and because of old config option names.

Change-Id: If79c554b46c44a7f70f8367426e7da362d7234c8
Related-Bug: #1732947
(cherry picked from commit a4eebd5de7ef4b63082536718ba7b993a66d47e7)
(cherry picked from commit c7991653a4e7cbb86656e6ba7579a86236801567)
(cherry picked from commit fe5e3e7e61d879f7a28eb177e4bdbc7ead3ae4ac)

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-12-05 15:44:12.000000000', 'message': 'Get original image_id from volume for volume-backed instance rebuild

A volume-backed instance will not have the instance.image_ref
attribute set, to indicate to the API user that it is a volume-backed
instance.

Commit 984dd8ad6add4523d93c7ce5a666a32233e02e34 missed this subtle
difference with how instance.image_ref is used, which means a rebuild
of any volume-backed instance will now run through the scheduler, even
if the image_href passed to rebuild is the same image ID as for the
root volume.

This fixes that case in rebuild by getting the image metadata off the
root volume for a volume-backed instance and compares that to the
image_href passed to rebuild.

Change-Id: I48cda813b9effa37f6c3e0cd2e8a22bb78c79d72
Closes-Bug: #1732947
(cherry picked from commit 54407afef3b446e34c44ba5392ccbf121e266de2)
(cherry picked from commit 4e36c4bd0eab2be619991ae00454906e171720b6)
'}]
commit_message:
Get original image_id from volume for volume-backed instance rebuild

A volume-backed instance will not have the instance.image_ref
attribute set, to indicate to the API user that it is a volume-backed
instance.

Commit 984dd8ad6add4523d93c7ce5a666a32233e02e34 missed this subtle
difference with how instance.image_ref is used, which means a rebuild
of any volume-backed instance will now run through the scheduler, even
if the image_href passed to rebuild is the same image ID as for the
root volume.

This fixes that case in rebuild by getting the image metadata off the
root volume for a volume-backed instance and compares that to the
image_href passed to rebuild.

Change-Id: I48cda813b9effa37f6c3e0cd2e8a22bb78c79d72
Closes-Bug: #1732947
(cherry picked from commit 54407afef3b446e34c44ba5392ccbf121e266de2)
(cherry picked from commit 4e36c4bd0eab2be619991ae00454906e171720b6)

commit_message:
Align tox_install.sh with other projects

pip_install.sh is renmaed to tox_install.sh.

The tox_install.sh here behaves a bit differently than the others, which
is causing some problems when trying to rework some of the shared gate
jobs.

Align it to the form used in other repos.

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-12-07 09:04:54.000000000', 'message': 'Remove partial sample config

Instead of having a partial sample config that may be outdated, have
users reference the config file the can be generated from source by
running "tox -e genconfig". Also change the name of the generated config
so that it is covered by our .gitignore and matches the README.

Change-Id: I49afb68a170abffaf7852dd7a2dc837e4cf4a756
'}]
commit_message:
Remove partial sample config

Instead of having a partial sample config that may be outdated, have
users reference the config file the can be generated from source by
running "tox -e genconfig". Also change the name of the generated config
so that it is covered by our .gitignore and matches the README.

Change-Id: I49afb68a170abffaf7852dd7a2dc837e4cf4a756

for group and group_snapshot create API.

In this patch, I have removed those extra parameters.

[1] https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/block-storage/v3/index.html#group-snapshots
[2] https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/block-storage/v3/index.html#generic-volume-groups

Change-Id: I29e7d4c8a3eee52f4ea7278d2edf2c7deec40628
"}, {'created': '2017-12-14 07:43:24.000000000', 'message': "Removed unnecessary parameters from group and group_snapshots create APIs

As per code, the 'status', 'user_id' and 'project_id' parameter
is not required to be passed in the request body in case of group
and group_snapshot create APIs. Even if you pass these parameter,
it is silently ignored in the code.

This patch removes those parameters passed in the request body.

Change-Id: I29e7d4c8a3eee52f4ea7278d2edf2c7deec40628
"}]
commit_message:
Removed unnecessary parameters from group and group_snapshots create APIs

As per code, the 'status', 'user_id' and 'project_id' parameter
is not required to be passed in the request body in case of group
and group_snapshot create APIs. Even if you pass these parameter,
it is silently ignored in the code.

This patch removes those parameters passed in the request body.

Change-Id: I29e7d4c8a3eee52f4ea7278d2edf2c7deec40628

commit_message:
Only query BDMs once in API during rebuild

We were unnecessarily looking up BDMs from the database
more than once during rebuild in the API. This makes that
a single read.

Change-Id: Iab929210d11336d09d9eef14ff6904e630ba195a
(cherry picked from commit 718e5af486c2e4011a4738285deac945993d5d5f)
(cherry picked from commit 6c1a0889bc124be327324466b48f2246a0cf0ad1)

commit_message:
rabbitmq: handle Debian and aarch64 properly

Debian 'stretch' has rabbitmq-server 3.6.10 in backports repository so
we will use it instead of external version.

Also take care of 'erlang-base-hipe' (or rather lack of it) on AArch64
architecture.

Depends-on: I72d1d1c10cbc4c5fe0907e395b6d7c969353dff8

Change-Id: Id332215b1e05e6edf18efd85c4463993bb7b321f

commit_message:
rename web_app placement-api to nova-placement-api to align with package

* The nova-placement-api package creates a "nova-placement-api.conf" in
apache2 sites-available, which currently leads to two conflicting
configurations (our "placement-api.conf" and the one from the package
"nova-placement-api.conf"). With this change the
"nova-placement-api.conf" will be replaced with our version of it.

Change-Id: I8ee7f190a6d73cace60a5fcd6b58d6b4e0288a95

commit_message:
Fix subnet enabled DHCP failed when subnet has port.

"get_insert_uuid" is the attribute of ovs-idl, not ovn-Transaction.
And subnet_dhcp_cmd.result is None when it not commited.

We can set subnet_dhcp_option command to port dhcpv4_options columns,
When LsPort's run_idl it can get the uuid with dhcpv4_options.result.

Change-Id: I1750962841921e58d7802c23d002ddf6d26e07a5
Closes-Bug: #1737980

commit_message:
Remove local manager.py

All tempest plugins were instructed to copy manager.py locally while
refactoring took place in tempest. Now that the refactoring is complete,
barbican-tempest-plugin should have its own manager.py deleted, and
import directly from tempest instead.

Change-Id: I40268822c6a2c6ef245f03863c2c3379da50acd7

commit_message:
Remove _get_subnets_by_cidr from neutron/db/extraroute_db.py

There's no caller for _get_subnets_by_cidr [1].
Therefore, as suggestion from Miguel, this method should be removed.

[1] http://codesearch.openstack.org/?q=_get_subnets_by_cidr&i=nope&files=&repos=

Change-Id: I48cb8e1567ef0b202b37f930bfe7b65ef309db68
Partially-Implements: blueprint adopt-oslo-versioned-objects-for-db

Closes-Bug: #1738175

commit_message:
Fix starting cinder-api & cinder-scheduler failed.

Failed to start cinder-api & cinder-scheduler, because of an unexpected
keyword argument 'project_id' and 'user_id'. This patch will fix it.

Change-Id: I981883aff40be6a3c0bd638b9e7d75b5b178b7ff
Closes-Bug: #1738175

[{'created': '2017-11-01 09:45:20.000000000', 'message': 'Use assertRegex instead of assertRegexpMatches

In Python3, assertRegexpMatches & assertNotRegexpMatches
are deprecated in favor of assertRegex and assertNotRegex

Change-Id: I64667fb621b259fd2944713b71ffcb7af486dee6
'}]
commit_message:
Use assertRegex instead of assertRegexpMatches

In Python3, assertRegexpMatches & assertNotRegexpMatches
are deprecated in favor of assertRegex and assertNotRegex

Change-Id: I64667fb621b259fd2944713b71ffcb7af486dee6

commit_message:
Add Elasticsearch and Kibana

Adds Elasticsearch and Kibana to OSH, so we can leverage the OSH
gates for testing and verifying functionality. This allows for
the ability to use ceph backed PVCs for elasticsearch, and also
introduces the ability to run curator on elasticsearch indices to
clean up old indices.

Change-Id: I9eb9fb3347de13d8161ca553a5c06d60e9e13b0c

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-11-30 10:50:01.000000000', 'message': "Support configuration of trunk ports

Trunk ports are necessary to support connectivity of VLAN networks between
multiple switches and to control plane nodes.  Currently only switch
ports corresponding to neutron ports are configured by the generic
switch driver.  This is a problem for some switches that do not support
adding a port to a VLAN that has not been created on the switch.

This change adds support for configuration of trunk ports when networks
are created and destroyed.  These trunk ports are configured via the
per-switch configuration option 'ngs_trunk_ports', which is a
comma-separated list.  Currently no drivers support this option.

Change-Id: I6c40f7f31058bc6e5e893743b6cdcd896d4850d1
Partial-Bug: #1690115
"}, {'created': '2017-12-14 09:17:38.000000000', 'message': "Support configuration of trunk ports

Trunk ports are necessary to support connectivity of VLAN networks between
multiple switches and to control plane nodes.  Currently only switch
ports corresponding to neutron ports are configured by the generic
switch driver.  This is a problem for some switches that do not support
adding a port to a VLAN that has not been created on the switch.

This change adds support for configuration of trunk ports when networks
are created and destroyed.  These trunk ports are configured via the
per-switch configuration option 'ngs_trunk_ports', which is a
comma-separated list.  Currently no drivers support this option.

Change-Id: I6c40f7f31058bc6e5e893743b6cdcd896d4850d1
Partial-Bug: #1690115
"}]
commit_message:
Support configuration of trunk ports

Trunk ports are necessary to support connectivity of VLAN networks between
multiple switches and to control plane nodes.  Currently only switch
ports corresponding to neutron ports are configured by the generic
switch driver.  This is a problem for some switches that do not support
adding a port to a VLAN that has not been created on the switch.

This change adds support for configuration of trunk ports when networks
are created and destroyed.  These trunk ports are configured via the
per-switch configuration option 'ngs_trunk_ports', which is a
comma-separated list.  Currently no drivers support this option.

Change-Id: I6c40f7f31058bc6e5e893743b6cdcd896d4850d1
Partial-Bug: #1690115

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-12-11 14:18:09.000000000', 'message': "determine influxdb version on each request if required

When determining influxdb version, the code relies on results of
SHOW DIAGNOSTICS. It is unknown when version banner appeared in
the output of the query, so in case we can't find it there the
version is assumed to be < 0.10.

However, it is incorrect to assume that any error means that
the version is < 0.10. Sometimes error means that influxdb is not
ready to serve connections yet. Ignoring these errors leads to
incorrect state of the application.

Try determining version of influxdb on application startup.
If it fails, retry the attempt on each request.

Change-Id: I813201e0410150cb9c81117232ac3986423e7503
Story: 2001313
Task: 5867
